utterances: Here's NPR's Brian Naylor.
I actually started off in black activism, working on issues that were important to black people.
And how that came about is just that I kind of just realized I cared one day and that there's a role for all of us.
For some of us, that role is to be out on the frontline, for some of us is to write the checks.
And I always tell people that exact same scenario.
It's like you need to figure out what your role is in the movement.
We don't all have to be out on the frontlines, but we do all need to understand that there is a movement that's going on that needs all of our participation.
And again, it's not just an LGBT movement.
Like I said, there are, you know, we are African-American same-gender loving people so we have a lot of issues.
We have the issues of not only just being gay, but also still being African-American and also going through the same things that other African-Americans are going.
I don't live in West Hollywood.
I don't, you know, I still live in the 'hood, you know.
I'm just as likely to be pulled over for being black.
You know, not for being gay, but for being black.

So its one of those things I think especially now, today, because there is a lot more activism and a lot more visibility - you mentioned television - that younger people like Mark are more comfortable to come out.
Because if I look around today, I work in Compton, I see so many more out young black women and men from my days when I was in school, which was just 10, 15 years ago.
Well, you know, let me ask you about language, though.
You used the term same-gender loving people.
Right.
You know, as we cover things here like the AIDS crisis, there's the term men who have sex with men as opposed to gay men.
What does language have to do with identity?
Why do you use the term that you do?
What has changed in this whole terminology around sexuality?
I used SGL, same gender loving, because I embrace it as sort of an African-American term to refer to as lesbian, gay bisexual and transgender people.
It's not a term that I coined or created but is one that is used frequently in our community.
And it's just a sense of ownership that, you know, we are black, you know.
When you hear same-gender-loving, nine times out of 10 it's in reference to African-American lesbian and gay folks.
And that's why I use it, because it's a sense of empowerment as well.
And sort of to put us aside like we are who we are and, you know, we bring not only our sexual orientation identity but also our culture and our race to the table as well.
Mark, I'm going to ask about dating, interracial dating.
You know, obviously you can have interracial dating in gay couples, straight couples, whatever terminology you choose.
Within the black gay community, as far as, you know, from your perspective, is there a taboo on interracial dating?
I don't want to say there's a taboo.
I don't see a lot of interracial dating.
I was raised in the Midwest so I've seen some here and there.
I think within the black community we are very family oriented.
And so it's all about the family.
You know, we can't disgrace the family and we have to worry about what the family thinks.
And I think being black and gay, that just adds something different to the pot.
That adds, like, if you're black and gay, you're in the middle because you've been kicked out of the family.
You disgraced the family.
You know what I mean?
But then your sexual orientation, you might not be able to identify with a white person, you know what I mean, because of the blackness.
So you're just in the middle.
So I think in regards to interracial dating that just makes it a little bit harder.
Vallerie?
Wow.
I think there is.
I there's an unspoken taboo.
I mean, I think there's still an unspoken taboo about interracial dating in the general black community.
And so, you know, we as black lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people are no different, you know.
It's kind of like Jasmyne said earlier: You know, I can't separate my blackness from my lesbianism because it's all a part of the same person.
But I think there is this sort of unspoken and sometimes a very verbal taboo against interracial dating in this community.
I've had friends that have told me that if they ever found me dating - if I was ever dating a white woman that I was no longer welcome in their homes.
What?
Or that I could come but I couldn't bring my partner kind of thing.

And I think, you know, I kind of laugh about that now, but I think it just speaks to a lot of internalized hatred, self-hatred, that we still harbor a lot of internalized homophobia, and not recognizing, you know, one, there are very few of us.
We are a small, limited community even though we think we're this huge community, and to some degree we are.
But the reality is love knows no color.
And I almost laugh when I hear myself say that.

I think people have a right to choose who they will share their affections with but, you know, I think to have some of the views that we have around interracial dating in this community are as dangerous as a lot of the views that white people hold about black people in general.
Jasmyne, I'm going to give you the last word.
Very briefly, do you wish that more prominent, you know, GLBT African-Americans were out?
Absolutely.
And hopefully conversations like the one that we're having today, shows like ""Noah's Ark"" and other shows that are in television will help to encourage more people to come out.
I think Vallerie had mentioned about not having any role models.
And that's part of what our job is today, is to make sure that people see us, that we're visible.
We're healthy.
We're alive.
We're doing big things and we're gay, and you can do the same, you know.
You don't have to commit suicide.
You don't have to, you know, be a mystery.
You can be who you want to be and still be black, gay and out.
All right.

The White House continued under an uncomfortable spotlight today as the press asked about the role of Karl Rove, the president's top policy adviser, formerly the deputy chief of staff, in the leak of a CIA officer's identity.
Mr. Rove is arguably the most influential presidential aide in history, yet the public knows very little about his personality and his history.
Tom Hamburger is a reporter for the Los Angeles Times and author of the forthcoming book ""One Party Nation: The Republican Quest for Dominance in the 21st Century."" He joins us here in Studio 3A.
Thanks very much for coming in to day.
Thanks.
Good to be here.
You published a story in the Los Angeles Times today outlining Karl Rove's long relationship with the Bush family.
How did he first come to the attention of the first President Bush?
Karl Rove was actually the subject of an inquiry by the first President Bush when he--in the early 1970s when he was chairman of the Republican National Committee.
Karl Rove, at the time, had--was a candidate for the leadership of the College Republican organization, and the election was disputed.
Rove was accused in essence of dirty tricks, of encouraging espionage on other candidates, and there were delegate selection contests.
The battle was so fraught for this organ--the chairmanship of this organization that it fell to the Republican National Committee chair, George H.W.
Bush, to rule to decide the dispute.

He reviewed the case, reviewed it pretty closely actually, assigned an FBI agent to question Karl Rove, and he came away convinced that Karl had done nothing wrong, but he was impressed by Karl Rove's drive and intellect and hired him right away as an aide to the Republican National Committee.
And a few--a bit later sent Karl Rove, this new aide, down to pick up his son, George W.
Bush, at the train station.
Exactly right, and it was--Karl Rove was awestruck at first sight.
He described meeting the young George W.
Bush coming off the train from Harvard Business School.
He was sent there to turn over the keys to the family car, and he said he'd never seen so much charisma in one person in all his life, and that was the beginning of a famous partnership.
Yet his partnership with the first President Bush, H.W.
Bush, did not end happily.

Well, it was--Karl Rove's career, although he is very much in the background in Washington, seldom interviewed publicly, not a frequent face on television, though that's changed in the last few weeks, his career has--because he is such an aggressive and skilled political player, and pushes the envelope on everything that he does, he has landed in controversy and he did, Neal, as you just suggested, land in some controversy when he worked for the first--for President Bush's--this is George H.W.
Bush's re-election campaign in 1992.
This would have been the race against Bill Clinton.
That's correct.

And during that race, there was an allegation that a Bush loyalist--there were only a few people in a room in which the Texas state chairman of the Bush campaign was berated and news of what happened to this Texas chair was leaked to a columnist by the name of Robert Novak.
Interesting, isn't it, since that's the name of the columnist to whom the current leak probe is--has in part been focused.
And the leak to Novak was what went on in this meeting in which the Texas state chair was berated.
The chair at the time, a fellow by the name of Rob Mosbacher, charged and, according to Houston Chronicle, still believes that Karl Rove was the leaker.
The Bush campaign in Washington apparently assented and Karl Rove was fired from the Bush campaign in 1992.
Now he does a lot of different things for President Bush.

I mean, obviously he's the man credited publicly by the president of the United States as the architect of his political victories as governor of Texas and then later two runs for president of the United States.

He has--my colleague with whom I wrote this article and worked the book, Peter Wallsten, and I believed that he probably has the broadest portfolio of any White House aide in history, and that he's accumulated more power in that in one office than any aide in history, but his official portfolio ranges across domestic and foreign policy.
But he is also the micro-manager of the Bush re-election, RNC election campaign and strategy, and oversees both the policy and the political.
At the same time--and we'll get back into some of these details in a moment--but at the same time, also in charge of the president's image and also a lot of policy.
That's correct.
The broad--the portfolio is so broad, and this is one of the things that interests us and that the public is learning as a result of this Plame investigation.

Karl Rove very much the man behind the scenes is actually, we now know from the Time magazine e-mails that have become public in this case, is someone who talks to reporters and does so providing background on a fairly regular basis.
What we know and what our reporting has shown is that it's the e-mails, the conversations with Matt Cooper of Time magazine, the Valerie Plame case, are not an isolated incident.
Karl Rove maintains contact with top reporters and editors at every news organization across this city.
Well, that might be part of the--one presidential aide has got to be in charge of that.
I mean, somebody's got to do it, right?
I suppose that's exactly right, Neal, though among the official titles that Karl Rove has, communications director is not one of them.
Not one of them.
Of course, he was only speaking on double super-secret deep background...
That's right.
...as the memo said.
We're talking with Tom Hamburger of the Los Angeles Times about his article today on Karl Rove.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And I'd like to get a little bit more into detail.
You were talking about during the re-election campaign, Karl Rove, I think is well known, electoral politics is his passion.

He understands things precinct by precinct, yet during the campaign you said he went around to various Cabinet agencies and talked about the various effects--how they could affect various things in various election races.
Neal, it's one of the things that we found most interesting in Rove's early years in the White House.

He and his deputy at the White House at the time, a guy named Ken Mehlman, who, of course, is now chair of the RNC, made it a practice of going to almost every one of the executive branch Cabinet agencies and addressing the political appointees.
Now, of course, political appointees are the managers of these agencies, and their briefing consisted of polling drawn from public sources.
There was a brief review of the president's priorities, and there were also a series of electoral maps at which--during which the battleground states were highlighted.
And we've had a couple of people who were in these meetings describe to us Rove and Mehlman's conversations.
At the Interior Department, for example, Rove would mention--where there were several important decisions pending, Rove, for example, mentioned an upcoming Senate race in Oregon.
At the time he addressed the Interior Department employees in early 2002.
The state's Republican incumbent senator, Gordon Smith, was thought to have a tough re-election battle ahead, and Rove made a point of this.

Everyone in the room knew that there was a huge decision pending at the Interior Department on the release of--it was--there was a drought in Oregon and whether to release water from the Klamath River.
And endangered fish--and this was a huge controversy.
In fact, water was denied to farmers by courts for a long time.
For endangered species reasons this became a huge political issue.
